fullDescription:
Primordial Goddess of Night - Mother of Dreams, Death, and Sleep

Nyx (ŒùœçŒæ) is the primordial personification of Night, born from Chaos at the beginning of creation. She is one of the most powerful beings in Greek cosmology, feared even by Zeus himself. As the mother of a vast brood of abstract deities - including Thanatos (Death), Hypnos (Sleep), the Oneiroi (Dreams), and the Moirai (Fates) - Nyx embodies the dark mysteries that frame human existence.

In Hesiod's Theogony, Nyx emerges from primordial Chaos alongside Erebus (the darkness of the underworld). Together, Nyx and Erebus produce Aether (the bright upper air) and Hemera (Day). This generation of light from darkness represents one of the fundamental cosmic polarities.

But Nyx's most significant offspring are those she bore alone, without a father - a dark parthenogenesis that produced the forces governing mortal life:

The Children of Nyx (Theogony 211-232):

- Moros (Doom)
- Ker and the Keres (Violent Death, Fates of Death)
- Thanatos (Peaceful Death)
- Hypnos (Sleep)
- The Oneiroi (Dreams)
- Momus (Blame, Mockery)
- Oizys (Misery, Suffering)
- The Hesperides (Daughters of Evening)
- The Moirai (Fates) - Clotho, Lachesis, Atropos
- Nemesis (Retribution)
- Apate (Deceit)
- Philotes (Affection)
- Geras (Old Age)
- Eris (Strife)

This catalogue reveals Night's dual nature: she brings both terror (Death, Doom, Strife) and respite (Sleep, Dreams, Evening). The alternation of night and day structures mortal life, and Nyx governs all that happens under her dark veil.

Power Beyond Zeus

Remarkably, Nyx is one of the few beings that Zeus himself fears. In Homer's Iliad (14.259-261), Hypnos recalls how he once put Zeus to sleep at Hera's request. When Zeus awoke in fury and sought to punish Hypnos, the god of sleep fled to his mother Nyx for protection:

'Quickly I fled and came to Nyx the Subduer, and Zeus stayed his wrath, mighty though he was, for he shrank from doing anything displeasing to swift Night.'

This passage reveals Nyx's primordial power - older than the Olympians, she commands respect even from the king of gods. Her domain of darkness is beyond the reach of Zeus's thunderbolt.

Cosmographic Role

Nyx dwells in Tartarus, in a house opposite that of Hemera (Day). The two never occupy the house at the same time; when one enters, the other exits, perpetually alternating. Hesiod describes this cosmic dance:

'And there the children of dark Night have their houses - Sleep and Death, awful gods... And there stands the dread house of dark Night wrapped in murky clouds.'

This cyclical alternation of Night and Day represents the fundamental rhythm of the cosmos - the daily death and rebirth that structures mortal existence. Nyx thus embodies cosmic time in its most primal form.

Orphic Cosmogony

In Orphic theogony, Nyx plays an even more central role. Some Orphic accounts make her, rather than Chaos, the first being - the cosmic egg emerging from her womb. She is called 'Nyx the dark-winged' and sits enthroned beside Phanes-Eros, the first-born god of creation. This elevates Night to the highest rank of primordial beings.

Cult and Worship

Nyx received limited cult worship in ancient Greece, her powers being too abstract and fearsome for regular devotion. However, she was honored at oracles and mystery cults, where the darkness of night was associated with prophecy, dreams, and revelation. The Ephesian temple of Artemis was said to contain an image of Nyx.
